title: 108_hr2630
content: The Act may be cited as the "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" or the "CASE Act of 2003." It introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens who possess critical reliable information about alien smuggling organizations and are willing to share this information with the authorities. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces a new class of nonimmigrant aliens who provide essential information about alien smuggling organizations to authorities for successful investigations and prosecutions. The "Commercial Alien Smuggling Elimination Act of 2003" introduces measures to prosecute individuals involved in alien smuggling organizations and limits the number of nonimmigrant visas for aliens providing information about such organizations to 400 per fiscal year. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to limit the number of nonimmigrant visas for aliens under a specific category to 400 per fiscal year. Additionally, officials are authorized to take necessary actions to protect the identity of such nonimmigrants and their family members. SEC. 3. Adjustment of status of nonimmigrant to that of person admitted for permanent residence. Section 245(j) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include provisions for nonimmigrants admitted under specific sections who provide information contributing to alien smuggling investigations or prosecutions. The Secretary of Homeland Security may adjust the status of aliens who provide information contributing to alien smuggling investigations or prosecutions, allowing them to be lawfully admitted for permanent residence. This adjustment also applies to nonimmigrants admitted under specific sections. The Secretary of Homeland Security can adjust the status of certain aliens to lawful permanent residence based on recommendations from the Secretary of State or Attorney General. If the identity of the person needs protection, officials can take necessary lawful actions. SEC. 4. BRINGING IN AND HARBORING CERTAIN ALIENS. Criminal penalties under the Immigration and Nationality Act are increased by up to 10 years for individuals who bring aliens into the US in violation of the law, under certain conditions. Additionally, a rewards program is established within the Department. A rewards program is established within the Department of Homeland Security to assist in eliminating commercial alien smuggling that endangers lives or presents a health risk to people in the United States. The rewards program, administered by the Secretary of Homeland Security, aims to eliminate commercial alien smuggling involving groups of 10 or more aliens in a manner that endangers lives or poses a health risk to people in the United States. Rewards may be paid to individuals providing information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards to individuals who provide information leading to the arrest or conviction of those involved in commercial alien smuggling of groups of 10 or more aliens that endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling of groups of 10 or more aliens that endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States, including acts such as aiding or abetting, prevention, or dismantling smuggling organizations. The Secretary of Homeland Security may offer rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling operations that endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this subsection. The Secretary of Homeland Security may offer rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in commercial alien smuggling operations that endanger lives or pose health risks in the United States. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this subsection, with ineligibility for government officials providing information while on duty and protection measures for informants. The Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of State, or the Attorney General can take lawful action to protect the identity of individuals providing information on alien smuggling. Rewards under this subsection cannot exceed $100,000 unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security. No reward under this subsection may exceed $100,000, unless authorized by the Secretary of Homeland Security for combating large-scale alien smuggling operations that endanger lives or pose a health risk to people in the United States. The transportation of aliens in groups of 10 or more must not endanger their lives or pose a life-threatening health risk to people in the United States. Rewards exceeding $50,000 require personal approval by the Secretary of Homeland Security. Any reward granted must be certified for payment by the Secretary. Additionally, an Outreach Program is established by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with other relevant authorities, will develop an outreach program to educate the public about penalties for harboring aliens and incentives for assisting in disrupting smuggling operations.
